title: Strings: Working with Text
description: Manipulate text using character arrays and string functions in C

concepts.title: Understanding Strings
concepts.content:
In C, a string is a sequence of characters stored as a character array. Unlike some programming languages that have a dedicated string type, C treats strings as arrays of characters.

A string in C is stored with a special character called the null terminator (\0) at the end. This character marks the end of the string and allows C to know where the string ends. For example, the string "Hello" is actually stored as 'H', 'e', 'l', 'l', 'o', '\0' - six characters total, with the last being the invisible null terminator.

When you declare a character array that will hold a string, you must make it large enough to hold all the characters plus the null terminator. For a 5-letter word, you need an array of at least size 6. A common mistake is forgetting to account for this extra byte.

You can initialize a string directly using a string literal: char name[] = "Alice"; or char name[10] = "Alice";. C automatically adds the null terminator for you.

You can also initialize an array of characters manually: char name[6] = {'A', 'l', 'i', 'c', 'e', '\0'};. Notice the null terminator is explicit here.

Strings are used extensively in real programs for storing names, messages, file paths, and any text data. Understanding how strings work and their representation in memory is crucial for C programming.

concepts.title: String Functions
concepts.content:
The C standard library provides many useful functions for working with strings. These functions are declared in string.h, which you must include with #include <string.h>.

The strlen() function returns the length of a string (not counting the null terminator). For example, strlen("Hello") returns 5.

The strcpy() function copies one string to another. The syntax is strcpy(destination, source), which copies the source string into the destination array. You must ensure the destination is large enough to hold the entire source string plus the null terminator. Failing to do so causes a buffer overflow, a serious security vulnerability.

The strcat() function concatenates (joins) two strings. strcat(str1, str2) appends str2 to the end of str1. Again, str1 must have enough space to hold both strings.

The strcmp() function compares two strings. It returns 0 if the strings are identical, a negative number if the first string comes before the second alphabetically, and a positive number if the first comes after the second. This is useful for checking if two strings are equal.

The strchr() function finds the first occurrence of a character in a string. It returns a pointer to that character, or NULL if the character is not found.

These string functions are fundamental for text processing, and understanding them is essential for C programming. However, they require careful use, especially strcpy() and strcat(), which can cause security issues if not handled correctly.

concepts.title: Reading String Input
concepts.content:
Getting string input from the user is a common task. C provides several methods, each with different characteristics.

The simplest is scanf() with the %s format specifier: scanf("%s", name);. This reads a string from the user until it encounters a space or newline. The main problem with this approach is that it doesn't check how much data it's reading, making it vulnerable to buffer overflow attacks. If the user enters more characters than the array can hold, extra characters will overflow into adjacent memory.

A safer approach is to specify the maximum number of characters: scanf("%9s", name); for a 10-character array. This tells scanf() to read at most 9 characters, leaving room for the null terminator.

Another method is gets_s(), which is a safer version of gets() that checks array bounds: gets_s(name, 20); reads at most 19 characters into a 20-element array.

The fgets() function is another option: fgets(name, 20, stdin);. It reads up to 19 characters from standard input and includes the newline character in the string if there's room.

When reading strings, always remember that the array must be large enough for the string plus the null terminator. It's good practice to use functions that check bounds to prevent buffer overflow vulnerabilities.
